title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ecclesiastes chapter 6 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ecclesiastes Chapter 6.

questions.question: What is described as an evil that the author has seen under the sun in Ecclesiastes 6:1?
options: A common evil among men
Poverty and hunger
War and destruction
False prophecy
questions.correctAnswer: A common evil among men
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:1 states there is an evil which is common among men under the sun.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:2, what happens to a man who has riches and honor but lacks power to enjoy them?
options: A stranger eats what he cannot enjoy
He shares it with his family
He gives it all to the poor
He builds a large house
questions.correctAnswer: A stranger eats what he cannot enjoy
questions.explanation: Verse 6:2 explains that God may give a man riches but not power to enjoy them, and a stranger eats them instead.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 6:3, what is said to be better than a man who has many children and years but no satisfaction or burial?
options: An untimely birth
A wealthy king
A wise elder
A poor servant
questions.correctAnswer: An untimely birth
questions.explanation: The verse states that an untimely birth is better than a man who lacks satisfaction and burial despite many children and years.

questions.question: What happens to the name of a man who departs in darkness as described in Ecclesiastes 6:4?
options: It shall be covered with darkness
It shall be remembered forever
It shall be written in the scrolls
It shall shine like the sun
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be covered with darkness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:4 says that his name shall be covered with darkness when he departs in darkness.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:5, who has more rest than the man who comes in vanity and departs in darkness?
options: One who has not seen the sun nor known anything
A wealthy merchant
A wise man
A king on his throne
questions.correctAnswer: One who has not seen the sun nor known anything
questions.explanation: Verse 6:5 states that one who has not seen the sun nor known anything has more rest than the man who comes in vanity and departs in darkness.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 6:6 teaches that even living a thousand years twice told guarantees seeing good.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 6:6 says that even if a man lives a thousand years twice told, he has seen no good.

questions.question: What is all the labor of man for according to Ecclesiastes 6:7?
options: For his mouth
For his children
For his wealth
For his kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: For his mouth
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:7 states all the labor of man is for his mouth, but the appetite is not filled.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:8, what does the wise have more than the fool?
options: Nothing
Wealth
Knowledge
Strength
questions.correctAnswer: Nothing
questions.explanation: Verse 6:8 asks what the wise has more than the fool, implying there is no difference in this context.

questions.question: What is said to be better than the wandering of desire in Ecclesiastes 6:9?
options: The sight of the eyes
A rich feast
A long life
A peaceful heart
questions.correctAnswer: The sight of the eyes
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:9 states that the sight of the eyes is better than the wandering of desire.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 6:10 says man may contend with him that is mightier than he.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 6:10 says man may not contend with him that is mightier than he.

questions.question: What question is asked in Ecclesiastes 6:11 regarding the increase of vanity?
options: What is man the better?
Who gains wealth?
Where is wisdom found?
Why do people suffer?
questions.correctAnswer: What is man the better?
questions.explanation: Verse 6:11 asks, seeing many things increase vanity, what is man the better?

questions.question: Complete the verse from Ecclesiastes 6:12: 'For who knoweth what is ______ for man in this life...?'
options: good
evil
wealth
power
questions.correctAnswer: good
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:12 begins with 'For who knoweth what is good for man in this life...'.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:12, how does the author describe man's life?
options: Vain and spent as a shadow
Joyful and prosperous
Strong and victorious
Long and peaceful
questions.correctAnswer: Vain and spent as a shadow
questions.explanation: Verse 6:12 describes man's life as vain and spent as a shadow.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 6:2 calls the inability to enjoy riches an evil disease.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 6:2 explicitly calls this situation vanity and an evil disease.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6:7 say about the appetite despite man's labor?
options: The appetite is not filled
The appetite is satisfied
The appetite grows stronger
The appetite is ignored
questions.correctAnswer: The appetite is not filled
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:7 states that although all labor is for his mouth, the appetite is not filled.

medium.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with contentment despite having material blessings. Based on Ecclesiastes 6, what biblical truth would you share about true satisfaction?
options: Having riches without the power to enjoy them is vanity and an evil disease
More wealth always leads to greater joy
The more children one has, the more fulfilled the soul becomes
Long life guarantees a meaningful and satisfied soul
questions.correctAnswer: Having riches without the power to enjoy them is vanity and an evil disease
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:2 teaches that even if God gives a man riches and honor so he desires nothing, without the power to enjoy them, it is vanity and an evil disease. This shows that true satisfaction is not in material blessings alone but in the ability to enjoy them.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 6 guide us in understanding the value of life and contentment in the face of many children and long years?
options: A soul not filled with good after many children and years is less blessed than an untimely birth
Having many children automatically fills the soul with joy
Long life is the ultimate blessing regardless of one’s inner peace
A man with many children is always honored in God’s eyes
questions.correctAnswer: A soul not filled with good after many children and years is less blessed than an untimely birth
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:3 explains that even if a man begets many children and lives many years, if his soul is not filled with good and he has no burial, an untimely birth is better. This teaches that inner contentment is more important than external blessings.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6 teach about the importance of enjoying the fruits of our labor in daily Christian living?
options: All labor is for one’s mouth, yet appetite is never fully satisfied
Working hard will always fully satisfy our desires
The wise always get more satisfaction from their labor than fools
Laboring for others is more important than for oneself
questions.correctAnswer: All labor is for one’s mouth, yet appetite is never fully satisfied
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:7 states that all labor is for the mouth, meaning to provide sustenance, yet the appetite is not filled. This teaches us to be grateful and content but also to recognize the limits of earthly labor.

questions.question: A believer feels envious of others’ desires and wants. What biblical insight does Ecclesiastes 6 offer about desires and contentment?
options: Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire
Chasing desires leads to true happiness
Ignoring desires completely is the best path
Desires always lead to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:9 teaches that it is better to be content with what one sees and has than to be consumed by wandering desires, which cause vanity and vexation of spirit. This encourages contentment and gratitude.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 6 caution us about trusting in long life or many descendants as a source of spiritual blessing?
options: Long life without a filled soul is vanity and darkness covers his name
Many descendants guarantee spiritual favor
Living long automatically leads to wisdom
A long life means a closer walk with God
questions.correctAnswer: Long life without a filled soul is vanity and darkness covers his name
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:4 explains that a man who comes in vanity and departs in darkness, with his name covered with darkness, is not truly blessed by long life alone, emphasizing the importance of spiritual fulfillment.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6 say about the futility of contending with mightier powers in life and faith?
options: Man cannot contend with Him who is mightier
Man should always strive to win over mightier powers
Fighting mightier powers brings great reward
Contending with mightier powers is a sign of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Man cannot contend with Him who is mightier
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:10 states that a man cannot contend with the mightier one, reminding believers to trust God’s sovereignty and not rely on their own strength in trials.

questions.question: A fellow believer wonders if wisdom truly makes a difference compared to foolishness. According to Ecclesiastes 6, how should you counsel them?
options: The wise has no advantage over the fool in the eyes of God
The wise always have more blessings than fools
Fools are rejected by God completely
Wisdom guarantees a better life
questions.correctAnswer: The wise has no advantage over the fool in the eyes of God
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:8 questions what the wise have more than the fool, implying that earthly distinctions may not ultimately matter, encouraging humility and reliance on God rather than human wisdom alone.

questions.question: What biblical truth about the uncertainty of life does Ecclesiastes 6 reveal to help us persevere through trials?
options: Man’s days are spent as a shadow and no one knows what comes after him
Life is certain and easily understood
The future is always bright for the righteous
Man controls all his days and destiny
questions.correctAnswer: Man’s days are spent as a shadow and no one knows what comes after him
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:12 tells us that man spends his vain life like a shadow and no one knows what will happen after him, reminding believers to trust God’s providence and remain faithful amid uncertainty.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 6 instruct us about the value of seeing and experiencing life over mere desire?
options: Seeing with the eyes is better than the wandering of desire
Desire is always more fulfilling than what is seen
The heart should only focus on desires
Desires lead to spiritual growth
questions.correctAnswer: Seeing with the eyes is better than the wandering of desire
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:9 emphasizes that it is better to appreciate what we have seen and experienced rather than constantly chasing desires, which leads to vexation of spirit, teaching the value of contentment.

questions.question: Based on Ecclesiastes 6, what would be a wise perspective on accumulating riches without the ability to enjoy them?
options: It is vanity and an evil disease
It is the ultimate sign of God’s blessing
It always leads to happiness
It guarantees peace of mind
questions.correctAnswer: It is vanity and an evil disease
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:2 reveals that riches without the power to enjoy them is vanity and an evil disease, teaching believers to seek God’s blessing of contentment, not just wealth.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 6 teaches that even living a thousand years twice told without seeing good is meaningless.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:6 states that even if a man lives a thousand years twice told and sees no good, it is meaningless, highlighting the importance of spiritual fulfillment over longevity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ecclesiastes 6, having many children and living many years always fills the soul with good.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:3 clarifies that even if a man has many children and lives many years, if his soul is not filled with good and he has no burial, it is better to be an untimely birth, showing that quantity does not guarantee fulfillment.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ecclesiastes 6 teaches that all the labor of man is for his ______, yet the appetite is not filled.
options: mouth
heart
wealth
children
questions.correctAnswer: mouth
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:7 states that all the labor of man is for his mouth, meaning to provide food and sustenance, yet the appetite is not filled, teaching the need for contentment and trust in God.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 6 encourage humility amidst human striving and ambition?
options: Man cannot contend with the mightier one
Man should always strive to be mightier than others
Ambition guarantees spiritual success
Striving always leads to earthly riches
questions.correctAnswer: Man cannot contend with the mightier one
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:10 reminds believers that man cannot contend with the mightier, encouraging humility and trust in God’s sovereign power over human efforts.

questions.question: What practical teaching about gratitude and stewardship can be drawn from Ecclesiastes 6?
options: Enjoying what God has given is better than chasing desires
Accumulating wealth is the primary goal of stewardship
Ignoring God’s gifts leads to blessing
Desires must always be pursued regardless of consequences
questions.correctAnswer: Enjoying what God has given is better than chasing desires
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:9 teaches that it is better to be content with what God has given than to chase after desires, encouraging gratitude and faithful stewardship of God’s blessings.

hard.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ecclesiastes Chapter 6.

questions.question: What is described as an 'evil which I have seen under the sun' that is common among men in Ecclesiastes 6?
options: A man given riches but unable to enjoy them
Corruption among rulers
The brevity of life
The pursuit of wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: A man given riches but unable to enjoy them
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:1-2 describes an evil seen under the sun where a man is given riches, wealth, and honor but cannot enjoy them, which is called vanity and an evil disease.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6, what is better than a man who begets many children but whose soul is not satisfied with good?
options: An untimely birth
A wise man
A poor man
A king
questions.correctAnswer: An untimely birth
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:3 states that an untimely birth is better than a man who has many children and lives many years but whose soul is not satisfied with good.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used when the text contrasts living many years without satisfaction and an untimely birth?
options: Chiasm
Parallelism
Typology
Foreshadowing
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The contrast between a long life without satisfaction and an untimely birth employs parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, as seen in Ecclesiastes 6:3-5.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 6:6, what rhetorical question emphasizes the futility of long life without enjoyment?
options: Do not all go to one place?
Who can understand the work of God?
Is there any profit in all labor?
What gain has the wise man over the fool?
questions.correctAnswer: Do not all go to one place?
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:6 asks rhetorically 'do not all go to one place?' highlighting the inevitability of death regardless of lifespan.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6:7 say is the purpose of all labor?
options: For his mouth
For his glory
For his soul
For his family
questions.correctAnswer: For his mouth
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:7 states that all the labor of man is for his mouth, indicating that work is primarily to satisfy hunger and needs.

questions.question: In the cultural context of ancient Near East, how might the inability to enjoy wealth, as described in Ecclesiastes 6:2, reflect on the concept of divine blessing?
options: It suggests divine blessing includes the ability to enjoy wealth, not just possession
It indicates that wealth alone guarantees divine favor
It implies wealth is unrelated to divine blessing
It shows that honor is more important than wealth
questions.correctAnswer: It suggests divine blessing includes the ability to enjoy wealth, not just possession
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:2 implies that mere possession of riches without the power to enjoy them is vanity, aligning with ancient Near Eastern views where divine blessing encompassed prosperity and enjoyment.

questions.question: Which theme in Ecclesiastes 6 is echoed in Psalm 39:6, where life is described as a fleeting shadow?
options: The vanity and brevity of human life
The joy of wealth
The power of wisdom
The certainty of judgment
questions.correctAnswer: The vanity and brevity of human life
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:12 refers to life spent as a shadow, similar to Psalm 39:6, emphasizing the transient and vain nature of human existence.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 6:9 states, 'Better is the sight of the eyes than the wandering of the desire.' What literary device is used here?
options: Antithetical parallelism
Chiasm
Metaphor
Simile
questions.correctAnswer: Antithetical parallelism
questions.explanation: The verse uses antithetical parallelism by contrasting the satisfaction of seeing with the frustration of unfulfilled desire.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:10, what is said about man's ability to contend with the mightier?
options: He may not contend with him that is mightier than he
He can overcome through wisdom
He is equal to the mightier by strength
He is always victorious
questions.correctAnswer: He may not contend with him that is mightier than he
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:10 says man cannot contend with the mightier, highlighting human limitation in the face of greater powers.

questions.question: How does Ecclesiastes 6:11 connect with the theme of vanity that permeates the book?
options: It notes that many things increase vanity, questioning man's improvement
It encourages seeking wisdom to overcome vanity
It promises reward for righteous living
It describes vanity as a fleeting moment
questions.correctAnswer: It notes that many things increase vanity, questioning man's improvement
questions.explanation: Verse 11 reflects on the growth of vanity in many things and questions what benefit man gains, reinforcing the book's central theme.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the theme of the futility of riches without enjoyment as seen in Ecclesiastes 6:2?
options: Luke 12:15 - 'Life does not consist in an abundance of possessions'
Matthew 5:3 - 'Blessed are the poor in spirit'
John 3:16 - 'For God so loved the world'
Romans 8:28 - 'All things work together for good'
questions.correctAnswer: Luke 12:15 - 'Life does not consist in an abundance of possessions'
questions.explanation: Luke 12:15 echoes Ecclesiastes 6:2’s theme by emphasizing that life’s value is not in wealth, but in contentment and enjoyment.

questions.question: True or False: Ecclesiastes 6 teaches that having many children guarantees a fulfilled soul.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:3 states that even if a man begets many children and lives many years, his soul may still not be filled with good, indicating many children do not guarantee fulfillment.

questions.question: What does the Hebrew term translated as 'vanity' (hebel) in Ecclesiastes 6 convey in its literary and theological context?
options: Meaninglessness, breath, or vapor
Joy and fulfillment
Strength and power
Eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: Meaninglessness, breath, or vapor
questions.explanation: The Hebrew word 'hebel' used throughout Ecclesiastes, including chapter 6, conveys the concept of transience and meaninglessness like a breath or vapor.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 6:5 says 'he hath not seen the sun, nor known anything.' What might this phrase typologically foreshadow in biblical literature?
options: The state of the unborn or the dead
The resurrection of the righteous
The coming of the Messiah
The exile of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The state of the unborn or the dead
questions.explanation: The phrase in Ecclesiastes 6:5 typologically alludes to the condition of the unborn child or the dead who have not experienced life’s pleasures.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 6:12 asks who can tell a man what shall be after him under the sun. This reflects what kind of ancient Near Eastern worldview?
options: A pessimistic uncertainty about the afterlife
A confident assurance of resurrection
A belief in reincarnation
A doctrine of predestination
questions.correctAnswer: A pessimistic uncertainty about the afterlife
questions.explanation: The verse reflects the ancient Near Eastern skepticism and uncertainty regarding life after death, common in wisdom literature.

theological.title: Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ecclesiastes Chapter 6 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:2, what is the condition of a man who has riches, wealth, and honor but lacks the power to enjoy them?
options: He experiences vanity and an evil disease
He is blessed abundantly
He is content and fulfilled
He is wise beyond measure
questions.correctAnswer: He experiences vanity and an evil disease
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:2 teaches that having riches and honor without the power to enjoy them results in vanity and an evil disease. This is consistent with Job 1:21, Psalm 49:10, 1 Timothy 6:7-8, and James 4:14, which highlight the futility of earthly wealth without God's blessing.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6:3 suggest about a man who has many children and lives many years but does not enjoy good life or have a proper burial?
options: An untimely birth is better than he
He is greatly blessed by God
He will inherit the kingdom of heaven
He is a wise man
questions.correctAnswer: An untimely birth is better than he
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:3 states that a man in such a condition is worse off than one who is born prematurely, emphasizing the futility of life without satisfaction or honor. This aligns with Psalm 39:4-6, Job 7:1-6, and Hebrews 9:27 which reflect on the brevity and vanity of life.

questions.question: How does the chapter describe the fate of a man who comes in vanity and departs in darkness, as per Ecclesiastes 6:4?
options: His name shall be covered with darkness
He will be remembered forever
He will be exalted among men
He will receive a crown of righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: His name shall be covered with darkness
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:4 describes such a man whose legacy is forgotten, signifying the fleeting nature of earthly life. This is supported by Ecclesiastes 1:11, Psalm 88:12, Isaiah 38:18, and Hebrews 11:13-16 emphasizing the transient nature of earthly remembrance versus eternal hope.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:6, even if a man lives a thousand years twice, what is said about his experience of good?
options: He has seen no good
He has achieved great wisdom
He has acquired much wealth
He has obtained eternal life
questions.correctAnswer: He has seen no good
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:6 reveals that longevity without fulfillment is meaningless, echoing Psalm 90:10, Job 14:1-2, James 4:14, and 2 Corinthians 4:18 which teach that life’s value is not measured by length but by purpose and relationship with God.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6:7 say about the labor of man and his appetite?
options: All the labor of man is for his mouth, yet the appetite is not filled
Man’s labor satisfies his deepest desires
The appetite is always fully satisfied
Labor is only for earthly possessions
questions.correctAnswer: All the labor of man is for his mouth, yet the appetite is not filled
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:7 indicates the insatiability of human desires, reflecting the truth found in Proverbs 27:20, Ecclesiastes 1:8, Philippians 4:11-13, and Psalm 107:9, showing that true satisfaction comes from God, not from worldly gain.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 6:8 raises a question comparing the wise and the fool. What is this question?
options: What hath the wise more than the fool?
Who is greater, the rich or the poor?
What is the meaning of life?
Who is truly righteous before God?
questions.correctAnswer: What hath the wise more than the fool?
questions.explanation: Verse 8 questions the advantage of wisdom over folly, emphasizing the vanity of human achievements apart from God. This aligns with Proverbs 1:7, Ecclesiastes 2:13-14, Romans 3:10, and 1 Corinthians 1:18 which contrast human wisdom with divine wisdom.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:9, what is considered better than the wandering of desire?
options: Better is the sight of the eyes
Greater is the strength of the body
Wiser is the heart of man
Higher is the spirit of the righteous
questions.correctAnswer: Better is the sight of the eyes
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6:9 teaches that seeing what is real and present is better than chasing after unfulfilled desires, which leads to vexation of spirit. This is consistent with Job 24:1, Proverbs 13:12, Psalm 37:4, and Matthew 6:33 emphasizing contentment and trust in God’s provision.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6:10 say about what has been named and known?
options: That which hath been is named already, and it is known that it is man
New things are continuously created by man
Man can contend with the mightier
Man is the creator of all things
questions.correctAnswer: That which hath been is named already, and it is known that it is man
questions.explanation: This verse highlights human limitations and the repetitive nature of life, consistent with Ecclesiastes 1:9, Romans 8:20-21, Job 38:4-7, and Psalm 8:4-6 which acknowledge God's sovereignty over creation and human finiteness.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 6:11 speaks of many things that increase vanity. What question does it pose about man?
options: What is man the better?
How can man achieve eternal life?
What is wisdom to man?
Who can save man from sin?
questions.correctAnswer: What is man the better?
questions.explanation: The verse questions the benefit of human efforts that only increase vanity, paralleling Psalm 144:3-4, Isaiah 40:6-8, Job 7:17-18, and 1 Corinthians 15:19 which emphasize human frailty and the need for divine intervention.

questions.question: What does Ecclesiastes 6:12 say about the knowledge of what is good for man in life?
options: Who knoweth what is good for man in this life?
All men clearly understand what is good
Man is destined to judge what is good
The wise have full knowledge of life’s purpose
questions.correctAnswer: Who knoweth what is good for man in this life?
questions.explanation: This verse expresses the uncertainty of discerning true good in life, which aligns with Jeremiah 17:9, Romans 7:15-20, Psalm 73:16-17, and Ecclesiastes 3:11 emphasizing human limitation and God's sovereign wisdom.

questions.question: Ecclesiastes 6:1 describes an evil under the sun that is common among men. What is this evil?
options: A man having riches but not enjoying them
A man living a long life full of joy
A man with wisdom and understanding
A man who shares his wealth generously
questions.correctAnswer: A man having riches but not enjoying them
questions.explanation: The chapter begins by identifying a common evil: wealth without the enjoyment of it, showing life’s vanity apart from God's blessing. This is supported by Psalm 73:3-16, Job 21:7-13, Luke 12:15, and 1 Timothy 6:9-10.

questions.question: In Ecclesiastes 6:5, what is said about the man who has not seen the sun nor known anything?
options: This hath more rest than the other
He is more blessed than the wise
He will inherit eternal life
He is less fortunate than all
questions.correctAnswer: This hath more rest than the other
questions.explanation: Verse 5 suggests that death without suffering is better than a life of vanity without enjoyment, aligning with Job 3:11-19, Psalm 88:10-12, Ecclesiastes 4:2, and Isaiah 57:1-2 which reflect on the peace of rest in death.

questions.question: According to Ecclesiastes 6:7, what is the relationship between man’s labor and appetite?
options: Labor serves the mouth but appetite is never filled
Labor fully satisfies the appetite
Appetite controls labor completely
Labor is independent of appetite
questions.correctAnswer: Labor serves the mouth but appetite is never filled
questions.explanation: This verse highlights human insatiability, consistent with Proverbs 27:20, Ecclesiastes 1:8, and Philippians 4:12-13, teaching that human striving alone cannot satisfy the soul’s deepest longings.

questions.question: What theological theme is most strongly emphasized in Ecclesiastes 6 regarding human existence?
options: The vanity and futility of life without God’s blessing
The eternal reward for earthly wisdom
The supremacy of human effort in achieving happiness
The certainty of man’s self-sufficiency
questions.correctAnswer: The vanity and futility of life without God’s blessing
questions.explanation: Ecclesiastes 6 repeatedly stresses the emptiness of riches, long life, and human labor without divine favor, echoing themes from Ecclesiastes 1:2, Psalm 39:5, Job 1:21, and John 15:5 about dependence on God for true meaning.

questions.question: What eschatological implication does Ecclesiastes 6:4-6 hint at regarding human life and death?
options: Life’s brevity and the inevitability of death
Resurrection and eternal life
Immediate judgment after death
The final defeat of death by man
questions.correctAnswer: Life’s brevity and the inevitability of death
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize the fleeting nature of life and the darkness of death, themes supported by Hebrews 9:27, Psalm 90:3-6, Job 14:14, and 1 Thessalonians 4:13-14, pointing to the human condition awaiting God’s ultimate redemption.
